And daily, in the temple and in every house, they ceased not to preach, to teach, and preach Jesus Christ. That is a commitment to obedience. Amen? Obedience is critical. Obedience requires commitment. See, when we truly understand who God is and we understand His authority in our lives, we say, I'm going to obey God. There's really no other option for me but to obey God. I understand I can disobey, but as I'm considering it spiritually, as I'm looking at the truth of God's Word, why would I want to disobey? I understand this evening that we're humans and we struggle, but the reality is that in the power of God and with His help, we ought to say, I'm going to obey God. I'm going to obey God. And the commitment to obedience that we see in Acts 5 is convicting to me. It's convicting to me. And I look at this passage of Scripture and I wonder tonight how committed am I to obeying God? I've already said it, it's been easy in our nation to obey God. I made this statement a few Sundays ago. I believe it was July 3rd, so a month ago. I made the statement that we could go out after church and we can preach and we can give Gospel tracts and we don't have to have any fear. No one's going to do anything to us. I made that statement on July 3rd, Sunday morning, preaching from this pulpit, and that afternoon I read of a preacher in the state of Washington that was arrested for preaching on the corner. And I thought, oh my. I just said a couple hours ago that we live in a nation where we can do that. It's changing, it's changing. But God has not changed. He's the same yesterday and today and forever. Listen, your circumstances might change, but God doesn't change. You make a commitment to obey God in the area of your finances. You expect that there's going to be some unexpected bills. Right? Why? Because Satan wants to find out if you're serious. Oh, you're going to obey God? I read a story about a man that said, man, I want God's blessing on my finances and I'm going to tithe and I'm going to give to God's work and I'm going to make this commitment. And all of a sudden, he didn't have an abundance anymore. Well, I just don't think I can afford to do it. Did God change? I'm going to make a commitment that I'm going to be a bold witness. I'm going to share the gospel of Jesus Christ with people. All of a sudden, you make that commitment and someone's going, hey, you can't talk about that here. Somebody's going to slam a door. Somebody's going to, I'm going to call the police. They're going to, why are we committed to obeying God? And so I ought to obey God. If I want God's blessing, and I do, I believe that we want God's blessing, we better get back to obedience. Not taking the approach of Saul in 1 Samuel 15, and excusing our disobedience, justifying our partial obedience. Well, we were going to do this, and I was going to do that. God says, no, no, no, what did I say? That's not what I told you to do, Saul. I was clear. When we go to the word of God, listen, if we really want to know what God wants us to do, we can find it. If we want to justify our disobedience, you know what I found in life? We can figure out a way to do it, just like Saul did. And this evening, we just make a commitment. Why? Because to obey is better. To obey is better. It is critical, obedience is critical. But obedience requires commitment. I wonder tonight, how committed am I to obeying the word of God? I mean, I'm not talking about when it's easy to obey, when it's convenient to obey. When everyone else is obeying. I'm talking about when the pressure comes.
